Module MathUtils
Package mathUtils.calculus

Class MathTools

java.lang.Object
mathUtils.calculus.MathTools
public final class MathTools
extends java.lang.Object
This class contains functionalities that are not available in java.lang.Math. Additions include summation, binomial coefficient and factorial, as well as other useful utilities.

  • Field Summary

    Fields
    Modifier and Type Field Description
    static double INFINITESIMAL
    This variable is an infinitesimal, a number infinitely close to another value.

  • Field Details

    • INFINITESIMAL

      public static final double INFINITESIMAL
      This variable is an infinitesimal, a number infinitely close to another value. It represents:

      \( \displaystyle\lim\limits_{x \to \infty} \dfrac{1}{x} \)

      and is equivalent to \( 10^{-10} \) or Math.pow(10, -10), as that is the double closer to any other to the limit's solution.

  • Method Details

    • round

      public static double round​(double n, int decimal)
      Rounds the given number to the given decimal. If the given decimal is negative, then the number is rounded to the nearest decimal.
      Parameters:
      n - The number to round
      decimal - The decimal
      Returns:
      The result

    • sum

      public static double sum​(int a, int b, Function f)
      Computes the sum from \(a\) to \(b\) for the given function \(f\). It is equivalent to:

      \( \displaystyle\sum\limits_{k=a}^b f(k) \)

      This can be written as:
      sum(a, b, f);
      To describe a function where you need to use the index of the summation as a variable, like:

      \( f(x) = \displaystyle\sum\limits_{k=a}^b \dfrac{x^2}{k} \)

      You should write:
      Function f = x -> sum(a, b, k -> x*x / k);
      For \( a > b \) the result is always \(0\).
      Parameters:
      a - The lower bound of the sum
      b - The upper bound of the sum
      f - The function to summate
      Returns:
      The sum

    • product

      public static double product​(int a, int b, Function f)
      Computes the product from \(a\) to \(b\) for the given function \(f\). It is equivalent to:

      \( \displaystyle\prod\limits_{k=a}^b f(k) \)

      This can be written as:
      product(a, b, f);
      To describe a function where you need to use the index of the product as a variable, like:

      \( f(x) = \displaystyle\prod\limits_{k=a}^b \dfrac{x^2}{k} \)

      You should write:
      Function f = x -> product(a, b, k -> x*x / k);
      For \( a > b \) the result is always \(0\).
      Parameters:
      a - The lower bound of the product
      b - The upper bound of the product
      f - The function to multiply
      Returns:
      The product

    • factorial

      @Deprecated public static long factorial​(int n)
      Deprecated.
      Since this method returns a long, it is going to fail for numbers that exceed eight bytes. If you need bigger numbers, then use the MathTools.factorial2() method.
      Computes the factorial of the given number \(n\), which is equivalent to \(n!\), the product of any positive integer and all positive integers that precede it, except \(0\). Special cases:
      • For \(n<0\) The result is \(-1\), as there is no solution for negative numbers.
      • For \(n=0\) the result is \(1\).
      Parameters:
      n - The integer whose factorial should be calculated
      Returns:
      The factorial

    • factorial2

      public java.math.BigInteger factorial2​(int n)
      Computes the factorial of the given number \(n\), which is equivalent to \(n!\), the product of any positive integer and all positive integers that precede it, except \(0\). Special cases:
      • For \(n<0\) The result is \(-1\), as there is no solution for negative numbers.
      • For \(n=0\) the result is \(1\).
      Note that this method is identical to MathTools.factorial() with the exception that it returns a BigInteger instead of a long, thus being able to yield greater values.
      Parameters:
      n - The integer whose factorial should be calculated
      Returns:
      The factorial

    • binom

      public static long binom​(int n, int k)
      Computes the binomial coefficient of \(n\) and \(k\). For any \( n \ge k; \; \; n,k \in \mathbb{N}^{\ne 0} \) counts:

      \( \displaystyle\binom{n}{k} = \dfrac{n!}{k!(n-k)!} \)

      Special cases and simplifications:
      • For any \(n < k\) and for any \(k<0\) the result is \(-1\), as no solution exists.
      • For any \(n=k\) and for \(k=0\) the result is always \(1\).
      • For \(k=1\) the result is always \(n\).
      Parameters:
      n - The first coefficient
      k - The second coefficient
      Returns:
      The binomial coefficient of n and k

    • limit

      public static double limit​(double c, Function f)
      Computes the limit of a function \( y = f(x) \) as \( x \) approaches a certain value \( c\). Note that the limit's solution is not exact, as it is computed in a numerical way. This method expresses:

      \( \displaystyle\lim\limits_{x \to c} f(x) \)

      This can be written as:
      double lim = limit(c, f);
      To describe a function with a limit that uses the limit's variable, like:

      g(x) = \( \displaystyle\lim\limits_{h \to 0} \dfrac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h} \)

      Write:
      Function g = x -> limit(0, h -> ( f.y(x+h) - f.y(x) ) / h);
      Parameters:
      c - The value that is being approached by \( x \)
      f - The function whose limit should be evaluated
      Returns:
      The limit of the given function f as x approaches c

    • clamp

      public static double clamp​(double x, double a, double b)
      Clamps the given value to match the given bounds. That is, the given value \( x \) may not be outside of the given bounds. Otherwise, it is equal to the nearest limit.
      For example, the line clamp(6, -5, 5) returns 5, because the given value is outside of the upper bound.
      The code is identical to:
      return (x < a)? a : (x > b)? b : x;
      Parameters:
      x - The value to clamp
      a - The lower bound
      b - The upper bound
      Returns:
      A value within the permitted bounds

    • root

      public static double root​(double x, double n)
      Calculates the n-th root of the given number. It is identical to: Math.pow(x, 1/n).
      Parameters:
      x - The number whose root should be calculated
      n - The root of the number
      Returns:
      The n-th root of the given number

    • square

      public static double square​(double x)
      Squares the given number. This method delegates to: Math.pow(x, 2).
      Parameters:
      x - The number to square
      Returns:
      The squared number

    • log

      public static double log​(double x, double n)
      Calculates the logarithm of the given number with the given base. It is identical to: Math.log(x) / Math.log(n).
      Parameters:
      x - The number whose logarithm should be calculated
      n - The base of the logarithm
      Returns:
      The logarithm of the given number with the given base

    • ln

      public static double ln​(double x)
      Returns the natural logarithm of the given number. This method simply delegates to: Math.log(x).
      Parameters:
      x - The number whose natural logarithm should be calculated
      Returns:
      The natural logarithm of the given number

    • isWithinBounds

      public static boolean isWithinBounds​(double x, double a, double b)
      Calculates whether or not the given value is between two other values. This method is identical to:
      return (x >= a) && (x <= b);
      Parameters:
      x - The value
      a - The lower bound
      b - The upper bound
      Returns:
      Whether or not the given value is between the given bounds

    • mean

      public static double mean​(double... values)
      Returns the mean of the given values.
      Parameters:
      values - The values
      Returns:
      The mean of the values
